direct_answer.text: Firstly, we add up all the pages that Solo needs to read from each subject: 4 (Science) + 405027 (Social Studies) + 7 (History) + 8 (Geography) equals a total of 405046 pages. Since he already read 15 pages last Monday, subtract these from the overall amount needed: 405046 - 15 makes it equal 405031 remaining pages. To find out how many pages he reads daily over the next four days, divide this new subtotal by the number of days available which was stated as '4'. This calculation results into roughly about 101257.75 pages per day. But since you cannot split a page, let’s round off to nearest whole numbers so Solomon would approximately require around 101258 pages every single day for those following days if no change happens during other activities or changes in requirements occur. 0.user_question: Solo has to read 4 pages from his Science textbook, 405027 pages from his Social Studies textbook, 7 pages from his History textbook and 8 pages from his Geography textbook. Solo read 15 pages on Monday. If he has 4  more days to complete all his reading, how many pages does he need to read, on average, in one day?

1.subquestion: How many pages should Solo plan to read per day if solo wants to finish within the next few days (excluding what he already read)?

subanswer.text: Solos needs to read 4+405027+7+8=405046 pages altogether minus the ones he already completed last week i.e.,  405046-(15)=405031 . And since he plans to do these tasks over 4days , then he would be required to divide the number equally among those days hence; 405031÷4≈ 101257.75 thus approximately about 101258 or round off upward because you cannot actually count partial page reads but rather whole numbers when doing homework therefore its safe to say ; Sola will take an approximate of ~(around) 101258pages daily until completion especially considering additional workload during school hours etc... In conclusion..the final figure seems quite high doesn't it?. But let us not forget even though alone might seem like such huge figures they aren't necessarily impossible! Well done :)
